sentence: Home improvement warehouse operator The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) said Tuesday that its first quarter profit jumped 41% from last year, prompting the company to boosted its full-year earnings guidance.
The Atlanta-based company reported first quarter net income of $725 million, or 43 cents per share, up from $514 million, or 30 cents per share, in the year-ago period.
Excluding one-time items, adjusted profit was 45 cents per share.
Sales rose 4.3% from last year, to $16.86 billion.
On average, Wall Street analysts expected a smaller profit of 40 cents per share, on lower revenue of $16.37 billion.
Additionally, Home Depot said its same-store jumped 4.8% in the quarter.
Same-store sales are considered a key indicator of a retailer's health, since they measure the performance of stores open at least one year.
Looking ahead, the company raised its full-year profit forecast to $1.88 per share, up from a prior outlook of $1.79 per share.
Analysts currently expect $1.87 per share for the year.
The company also predicted a 3.5% rise in full-year sales, up from a previous estimate of a 2.5% gain.
We have been recommending shares of HD since July 30, when the stock was trading at $25.39.
The company has a 2.64% dividend yield, based on last night's closing stock price $35.59.
The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) is a "recommended" dividend stock, holding a Dividend.com DARSâ„¢ Rating of 3.5 out of 5 stars.
